data.title: Monument to Francesc Ferrer i Guàrdia, Jardins de Joan Maragall, Montjuïc, Barcelona, Catalunya

data.text:
Given its location in a park between the Palau Nacional (Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya) and the 1992 Olympic stadium, one might be excused for misinterpreting (okay; I did) this bronze statue as depicting an athlete bearing the Olympic torch.

Instead, the statue by Auguste Puttemans (a replica of one installed in Brussels in 1911), was unveiled here in 1990 to commemorate Francesc Ferrer i Guàrdia (1859-1909), 'free thinker', republican and founder of the Escuela Moderna, which taught children in the context of then-radical social values. Exiled from Spain 1885-1901 and again imprisoned (without charge) 1906-08, Ferrer was arrested yet again in 1909 after the workers' uprising of la Setmana Tràgica and executed by firing squad here on Montjuïc.

Though Ferrer's education system was continued by Modern, or Ferrer, Schools in the USA, the statue was intended to, as the inscription states, "repair many years of neglect and ignorance of a man who died defending social justice, brotherhood and tolerance".
